 atelectasis in both lungs.  Small pleural blebs are present at the lung bases.
 There are no focal consolidations to suggest aspiration.  There are no lung
 nodules or masses.  No destructive lytic or blastic lesions are seen in the
 osseous structures of the torso.

 ABDOMEN CT W/WO CONTRAST:  On series 3, image 14, there is a 2 mm low
 attenuation lesion in the posterior segment of the right hepatic lobe which is
 too small to characterize.  No other focal liver lesions are seen.  There is
 no intra or extrahepatic ductal dilatation.  No abnormality is seen in the
 gallbladder, spleen, pancreas, adrenals, or kidneys.  The kidneys show
 symmetric nephrograms and excretion.  The visualized ureters have normal
 diameter.

 A large constricting circumferential mass is present in the antrum of the
 stomach, measuring approximately 7 to 10 cm in length and at least 15 mm thick
 in some portions of the wall.  The body and fundus of the stomach are markedly
 dilated, filled with food mixed with oral contrast.  There is no extravasation

 gastrohepatic ligament, the largest of which are 1 cm in the short axis.

 loops of small and large bowel are normal.  The patient is s/p aortobifemoral
 graft.  Tiny aneurysms are present at both anastomoses of the grafts with the
 common femoral arteries.  A left renal artery stent is present.  There is no
 retroperitoneal, pelvic, or inguinal adenopathy.  A small fat-containing
 hernia is present in the left inguinal canal.

 No abnormality is seen in the bladder.  The prostate is markedly enlarged and
 shows heterogeneous enhancement.

FINAL REPORT
 MESENTERIC ANGIOGRAM [**2177-3-25**].

 INDICATION:  55 year old woman with diabetes.  GI bleed identified from cecum
 Nuclear Medicine study.

 OPERATORS:  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 539**], Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 71035**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 539**], Staff Radiologist, was present
 for the entirety of the procedure and supervised Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 71035**].

 CONTRAST:  160 cc of non-ionic contrast was utilized.  Non-ionic contrast
 utilized secondary to the patient's history of multiple allergies.

 TECHNIQUE:  Informed written consent was obtained prior to beginning the
 procedure.  The patient was placed supine on the fluoroscopy table.  The
 patient's right groin was prepped with Betadine.  A sterile field was erected.

 Double-wall technique was utilized to access the right femoral artery.  A J
 wire was advanced to the level of L1 within the aorta.

 The needle was removed over the wire.  A 4-French sheath was placed over the
 wire.

 A 4-French Omni Flush catheter was advanced over the wire.  Hand injection
 demonstrated normal arterial anatomy.  A power injection angiogram
 demonstrated normal origins of the celiac axis, SMA, [**Female First Name (un) 85**] and renal arteries.

 The Omni Flush catheter was replaced for a C2.  Selective catheterization of
 the SMA was performed.  No sites of bleeding were identified along the course
 of the SMA and its branches.  The C2 catheter was replaced for a SOS catheter.
  Selective catheterization of the [**Female First Name (un) 85**] was performed.  Normal [**Female First Name (un) 85**] angiogram was
 demonstrated.

 A second selective catheterization of the SMA was performed.  Again, a normal
 angiogram was demonstrated.

 The catheter was removed.  The sheath was removed.  Pressure was applied to
 the groin for 15 minutes.  Following release of pressure, no bleeding was
 identified.  The right groin was cleansed and properly bandaged.

 The patient left the Angio Suite in stable condition.

 COMPLICATIONS:  No immediate complications were identified, nor were patient
 complaints logged.

 in the right posterior temporal lobe.  However, the [**Doctor Last Name 37**]/white matter
 distinction is preserved, and there is no evidence of territorial infarction.
 The carotid and vertebral arteries are calcified.  Also, there is moderately
 increased density of the blood seen in the circle of [**Location (un) **] and venous
 sinuses, suggesting either recent administration of contrast material or
 hemoconcentration.  The osseous structures, soft tissues, and paranasal
 sinuses are unremarkable.

 INDICATIONS: This patient is a 79-year-old male with an asymptomatic 7-cm
 abdominal aortic aneurysm noted incidentally on a CT scan for a small bowel
 obstruction. He presents for aortogram with evaluation for possible endograft
 repair.

 MEDICATIONS AND CONTRAST: The patient received no IV sedation during the
 procedure, however was continuously hemodynamically monitored throughout the
 case. 8 cc of 1% lidocaine were used as local anesthesia and a total of 240 cc
 of Optiray 60% contrast was used throughout the case.

 TECHNIQUE: After consent was obtained, patient was placed in the supine
 position on the fluoroscopy table and the right groin was shaved, prepped, and
 draped in the usual sterile manner. Common femoral artery was identified with
 the aid of fluoroscopic guidance using bony landmarks. 8 cc of 1% lidocaine
 local anesthesia were infiltrated at the site of the right common femoral
 artery and a 19-gauge single wall puncture needle was introduced into the
 right common femoral artery after a small skin [**Doctor Last Name **] was made with an #11 blade
 and 0.035" Bentson guidewire was then advanced through the needle and into the
 lower abdominal aorta. A 5-French sheath was then placed over the wire and its
 side arm was flushed throughout the case with heparinized saline. Over the
 wire, a 5-French marked Omniflush catheter was inserted to the level of L1 and
 abdominal aortogram was performed including AP and lateral views. The catheter
 tip was then withdrawn to the level of the lower abdominal aorta and right and
 left anterior oblique views of the pelvic arteriogram were performed.
 Subsequently, a bilateral femoral arteriogram was performed. The catheter was
 removed. The sheath was removed and adequate hemostasis was achieved with
 manual pressure at the puncture site. The patient tolerated the procedure
 well. No immediate complications were noted.

 FINDINGS: The celiac trunk is patent, although mild stenosis of the proximal
 celiac trunk is noted on the lateral view of the aorta. Patent single
 bilateral renal arteries are noted with the left renal artery being lower than

 infrarenal aorta.   The right iliac system is more tortuous than the left.

 arteries are also widely patent, as are the superficial femoral and profunda
 femoris arteries. Bilateral superficial femoral arteries have diffuse mild
 disease.

[**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  56 year old woman with DM, CAD, CRI, recent pericarditis/tamponade during this
  admission of unclear etiology.
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  Please evaluate pericardium.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Patient with recent pericarditis, tamponade of unclear etiology.
 Evaluate pericardium.

 TECHNIQUE:  A CT of the chest, abdomen and pelvis was performed following
 administration of IV and oral contrast.

 CT CHEST WITH CONTRAST:  A small amount of pericardial fluid is seen
 anteriorly and posteriorly with no evidence of loculation.  The pericardium
 enhances, but is not particularly thickened measuring approximately 2 mm.
 These findings are in keeping with the history of pericarditis.  There is no
 axillary, mediastinal or hilar adenopathy.  Small bilateral pleural effusions
 are seen with adjacent compressive atelectasis.  There are no intravascular
 filling defects with pulmonary arterial branches to suggest PE.  A non-
 specific density is visualized within the main pulmonary artery, of unclear
 etiology.  The central airways are patent.

 CT ABDOMEN WITH CONTRAST:  The patient is S/P cholecystectomy.  The common
 duct is dilated to 12 mm, possibly due to ampullary stenosis; however, a
 retained stone cannot definitively be excluded.  Pneumobilia is likely related
 to a previous sphincterotomy.  There are no focal hepatic lesions. The liver,
 spleen, adrenals and pancreas are normal in appearance.  The kidneys enhance
 promptly and symmetrically with sub-cm bilateral low attenuation lesions which
 are too small to characterize.  There is no hydronephrosis.  Small
 retroperitoneal lymph nodes are seen.  There is no ascites.  The bowel is
 unremarkable.

 CT PELVIS WITH CONTRAST:  A Foley catheter is in place.  Evaluation of the
 pelvis is limited secondary to streak artifact from a right hip prosthesis.  A
 left common iliac artery stent is in place.  The patient has had previous
 bypass surgery in the left groin region with post-operative changes.

 Evaluation of the osseous structures demonstrates degenerative changes.
